data.description:
Commit is the onchain accountability protocol that aims to make people accountable by adding crypto stakes. If someone doesn't deliver, their stake is shared among those who do.

Potential use cases:
1. Personal Goals: motivate yourself or friends to reach fitness goals, write every day, build other good habits, or whatever!
2. Events: Attendees stake crypto to get tickets. Show up, get it back. No-show, others get your stake.
‚Ä¶ and more!

We‚Äôre fully bootstrapped and iterating ‚Äî your support would mean a lot. Thank you!
data.title: Commit

data.description:
Due to emerging risks affecting Ethereum, core development, and its validator set, a group of teams and individuals is working on Commit-Boost, a public good initiative. Commit-Boost is an open-source Ethereum validator sidecar designed to standardize the final stage of communication between validators and proposer commitment protocols.

Developed from scratch in Rust with contributions from over 20 teams across Ethereum, Commit-Boost is built with safety and modularity at its core. It is designed to avoid restricting downstream market participants, including stakeholders, commitment flows, enforcement mechanisms, and proposer commitments. More details can be found in our second ETH Research post: https://ethresear.ch/t/commit-boost-proposer-platform-to-safely-make-commitments/20107

Our Guiding Principles
- Would Vitalik run this? Can this initiative enhance decentralization?
- Mission: Not-for-profit, community-driven, and fully open-source.
- Neutrality: Agnostic to proposer commitments, preconfirmations, restaking, relays, and transaction flows.
- Unification: A single validator-sidecar enabling participation in multiple commitment protocols.
- Safety: Community-reviewed and audited, modularized for flexibility, and designed for greater transparency‚Äîreducing risk and operational overhead for proposers managing commitments.

Milestones Achieved

Commit-Boost is already deployed in production with top validators. As of writing, 7% of Ethereum blocks are being produced via Commit-Boost. All proposer commitment teams are leveraging Commit-Boost, demonstrating broad support, and over 70 contributors from across Ethereum are helping/helped in various ways.

Impact

By driving standardization and unifying efforts across Ethereum, Commit-Boost helps mitigate risks to stakers and the Ethereum network while fostering an open playing field for proposer commitments. This will allow innovations such as preconfirmations for based rollups to thrive.

Funding Usage

Now that Commit-Boost is live in production, we are raising grant funds to support a full-time developer focused on two key areas:

1) Sustainment: As adoption increases, Commit-Boost will require ongoing development, feature enhancements, and refinements based on real-world usage.

2) Hardfork Support: A recurring challenge for core developers, researchers, and ETH Pandas is the lack of dedicated support for testing critical out-of-protocol infrastructure during hard forks. This burden has often fallen on them. The Commit-Boost team aims to fill this gap, ensuring smoother hard fork transitions and comprehensive testing.

We greatly appreciate the community‚Äôs support for this initiative!
data.title: Commit-Boost

data.description:
### The Challenge We‚Äôre Tackling
Across Kenya and around the world, communities possess rich traditions of mutual aid, ecological knowledge, and collective care. Yet these ways of living and giving are often invisible to the formal economy. When markets fail or extract value, people are left unable to coordinate the abundance already within reach: fertile land, skilled hands, cultural knowledge, and strong relationships. What if we could bring visibility and value to these hidden commons‚Äîreviving ancestral systems of cooperation to build resilient, regenerative local economies?

### Our Solution
Grassroots Economics supports communities to organize themselves through Commitment Pooling‚Äîa protocol inspired by both ecological systems and indigenous traditions like Mweria (rotating labor groups). Through Commitment Pooling, communities define what is valuable, coordinate labor and care, and exchange commitments using tools like the Sarafu Network, our blockchain-based voucher system.
Whether it‚Äôs in rural villages like Kiriba, peri-urban settlements, or refugee camps, communities use this protocol to regenerate ecosystems, build shared infrastructure, and care for one another‚Äîwithout needing formal currency. The result is a living, trust-based economy rooted in shared responsibility, long-term reciprocity, and ecological balance.

### Our Organisation / Community
Commitment Pooling is a community-led protocol developed by Grassroots Economics that enables people to coordinate resources, labor, and care without relying on money. Inspired by ancestral traditions like Mweria (rotating labor associations in Kenya) and ecological systems such as fungal networks, Commitment Pooling helps communities build collective trust and mutual service systems through shared commitments.

At its heart, Commitment Pooling is based on four core functions: Curation, Valuation, Limitation, and Exchange. Communities first curate what actions or services are valuable‚Äîsuch as planting trees, repairing homes, or caring for elders. They then value these contributions, ensuring all forms of labor and care are recognized. Through limitation, they agree on fair access and avoid overuse of shared resources. Finally, they exchange commitments using community agreements or digital tools like the Sarafu Network, a blockchain-based system that tracks and honors these commitments transparently.

This protocol transforms how communities organize collective action. Instead of waiting for outside funding or relying on scarce cash, people pool their promises and labor into a shared commons. These commitments become a kind of social currency, used to regenerate ecosystems, strengthen social bonds, and meet local needs.

Grassroots Economics implements Commitment Pooling across Kenya, helping communities like those in Kiriba, Kilifi, revive traditional knowledge and co-create resilient, regenerative economies. Each act of service becomes part of a living economy rooted in trust and reciprocity‚Äîshowing that care, not cash, is the foundation of sustainable development. Commitment Pooling is more than a system‚Äîit‚Äôs a return to the logic of life.


### üñºÔ∏è See Our Impact
![alt text](https://www.ecocertain.xyz/_next/image?url=%2Fapi%2Fhypercert-image%2F42220-0x16bA53B74c234C870c61EFC04cD418B8f2865959-64313367348057369594577800804604191965184&w=640&q=75)


### View Our Hypercert [here](https://www.ecocertain.xyz/hypercert/42220-0x16bA53B74c234C870c61EFC04cD418B8f2865959-64313367348057369594577800804604191965184)

### What This Hypercert Represents:
This hypercert documents the on-the-ground revival of rotating labor associations, mutual service exchanges, and ecological restoration across several Kenyan communities. It highlights the power of Sarafu vouchers and Commitment Pooling Protocols to coordinate thousands of hours of labor‚Äîplanting food forests, restoring water catchments, rebuilding homes, and strengthening social cohesion‚Äîall without money changing hands.

### Proof That It‚Äôs Working
From Kiriba to Mathare, communities using commitment pooling show real outcomes: improved food security, increased trust, and reduced dependence on volatile cash markets. Families are meeting weekly to regenerate their land and care for each other. Local schools, seed banks, and sacred groves are being protected and revived. All activities are tracked transparently via Sarafu, showcasing both social and ecological impact.

### Join Us in Making a Difference!
Your contribution supports a global shift‚Äîfrom scarcity to sufficiency, from extraction to care. Every seed you plant through this project helps a community revive its commons: rebuilding homes, restoring ecosystems, and strengthening the fabric of mutual support.
This isn‚Äôt charity‚Äîit‚Äôs co-creation. Together, we are building decentralized, resilient economies grounded in ancestral wisdom, ecological stewardship, and modern tools of coordination.
Act now. Another village is ready to rise. Let‚Äôs grow this network of care together.
data.title: Grassroots Economics Commitment Pooling

questions.query: Project GitHub Repo
questions.explanation: https://github.com/commitwtf/Commit-v0.1

questions.query: Have you participated in a previous Gitcoin Grants Round? If so, please name the rounds or link the builder profile associated with previous rounds.
questions.explanation: non-profit i've cofounded raised one of the largest Gitcoin grants funding in Ukraine (and potentially overall Gitcoin) specific round https://x.com/polats/status/1506850068510519296

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the growth of the OSS ecosystem? Please provide specific examples of how your application enhances or expands the current ecosystem.
questions.explanation:
- we're running experiment with v0.1 helping people 'Commit' to support public goods projects (and funding towards them)
- by increasing show-up count of people to events, workshops, hackathons, etc -- we increase # of devs building, projects' progress, and ultimately impact
- helping people become more accountable or completing fun / meaningful commits helps onboard more 'newbies' into web3 space, thus leading to larger adoption (coordinating activation campaigns atm with leading protocols, incl. Arbitrum)
- later on, we'll add 'PG fund / impact fund' and donate % of 'slashed' commits (by people who failed to deliver) to support OSS and larger public goods ecosystem

questions.query: What features or use cases does your dApp/App present? How is it differentiated?
questions.explanation:
We're enabling onchain accountability across variety of different use cases, yet starting with the focus on events and personal goals. 

In the next iterations, we'll be experimenting with exciting, progressively decentralised commit resolution primitives, as well as possibly advanced solutions like zkTLS, and more.

questions.query: What are your plans for further development, and how will the grant funds be used to achieve these goals?
questions.explanation:
- keep on bootstrapping and iterating, ship v2 as the next step (finishing frontend soon, smart contract is ready)
- talking to user and shipping what they want (reached out to ~1.8k people, ~400+ are waiting for the next version to try out)
- onboarding more partners and commit creators (have ~14 creators in the pipeline, incl. event orgs that'll use Commit for Bangkok Devcon activations for ~100+ users)
- iterating, iterating, iterating!

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the growth of the OSS ecosystem? Please provide specific examples of how your application enhances or expands the current ecosystem.
questions.explanation:
Our contracts are fully open-source (MIT and can be found on our GitHub repos or on block explorers.

Commit protocol encourages developers to build on top of it or enhance it, contributing to programmable accontability of both onchain and offchain actions across the ecosystem.

questions.query: What features or use cases does your dApp/App present? How is it differentiated?
questions.explanation:
Commit protocol combines credible commitments with financial and social incentives. 

Users can create a 'commit' (commitment/challenge) with a stake amount, deadlines, and optional extra rewards. Those who achieve their goals get their stake back, plus a share of the losers' stakes and any additional 'extra rewards' (erc20 tokens; soon more).

We believe we need more meaningful apps solving real problems ‚Äî not just speculation-driven ones. Commit offers a simple yet powerful primitive, and we believe it has the potential to become a viral social app beyond ‚Äòjust‚Äô crypto-natives. Millions of people love challenges and make commitments daily, often without realizing how central they are to life. 

Combining onchain accountability (credible commitments) with social and financial incentives could unlock new use cases and social behavior ‚Äî from small (private friend groups / onchain communities) to large coordination mechanisms (large-scale DAOs / orgs).

// latest demo: https://x.com/revrfg/status/1884426456572322231

questions.query: What are your plans for further development, and how will the grant funds be used to achieve these goals?
questions.explanation: We‚Äôre planning to improve the existing core flow of commits, onboarding UX, adding more social mechanisms (social sharing, inviting friends, activity feed, and more), and make important protocol-wide updates (such as milestone-based commits ft. customisable updates ‚Äî daily, weekly, etc)

questions.query: How does your project contribute significantly to the Ethereum network's infrastructure? Please provide specific examples and metrics if available.
questions.explanation:
Commit-Boost is a new validator sidecar that standardizes how validators interact not only with the PBS (Proposer-Builder Separation) pipeline but also with other commitment mechanisms, such as preconfirmations (preconfs)‚Äîall within a unified sidecar.
Without Commit-Boost, multiple competing sidecars would likely emerge, increasing risks for Ethereum stakers and adding complexity during hard forks. Further, today‚Äôs block construction process is highly centralized, Commit-Boost returns autonomy to Ethereum‚Äôs +1m proposers to put constraints around how builders must construct a block. By providing a single, standardized solution and the ability to constrain builders, Commit-Boost enhances **network security, reduces fragmentation, and streamlines operations for validators.**

Key Metrics & Impact:
-	Adoption: All preconfirmation teams (five different teams) are building on Commit-Boost.
-	Network Usage: Currently, ~7% of Ethereum blocks are being built through Commit-Boost, and this number is expected to grow.
-	Ecosystem Collaboration: Development has been supported by over 20 teams across Ethereum.

While Commit-Boost was not yet in a position to contribute to Pectra, we plan to assist with Fuska by helping update the PBS pipeline for the next hard fork and ensuring thorough testing.

questions.query: Describe any pioneering development work in your project, particularly in enhancing privacy, interoperability, or user experience.
questions.explanation:
One of the first use cases of Commit-Boost is preconfs, which are essential for enhancing the user experience (UX) of based rollups. Based rollups facilitate seamless interoperability between Ethereum and other based rollups, improving transaction efficiency and reducing latency.

Recognizing the potential of preconfs to enhance interoperability, multiple researchers at the Ethereum Foundation (EF) have spent the past few years advocating for this solution. Today, over 20 teams are actively working to turn this research into reality, leveraging Commit-Boost as a key component in its implementation.

questions.query: What specific problems or challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem does your project address? How does your solution improve upon existing alternatives?
questions.explanation:
Commit-Boost tackles several critical challenges in the Ethereum ecosystem, improving security, user experience, decentralization, and core development efficiency. Here‚Äôs how:
-	**Security & Efficiency:** Without Commit-Boost, validators would likely need to run multiple sidecars, increasing complexity and risks. Commit-Boost provides a unified sidecar, reducing operational overhead and enhancing security.
-	**Improved User Experience:** Currently, no existing sidecar supports proposer commitments, such as preconfirmations (preconfs), which are essential for based rollups and a seamless user experience. All preconf teams are building on Commit-Boost to enable this functionality.
-	**Open & Inclusive Design:** Commit-Boost fosters an open playing field, allowing anyone to build on it and any staker‚Äîincluding solo stakers‚Äîto run it. It also minimizes switching costs for proposers, preventing vendor lock-in from downstream participants.
-	**Enhancing Decentralization:** Today‚Äôs block construction is highly centralized. Commit-Boost enables proposers to set conditions and constraints on how their blocks are built, shifting power back to Ethereum‚Äôs 1M+ validator set.
-	**Supporting Ethereum Core Development:** During hard forks, core developers are currently burdened with making changes to the PBS (Proposer-Builder Separation) pipeline, diverting their focus from more critical tasks. Moving forward, Commit-Boost will take on these updates, ensuring smoother hard forks and freeing up core devs for higher-priority improvements.

questions.query: Outline your project's roadmap and how the grant funds will be used to achieve your development goals.
questions.explanation:
This grant will help fund a full-time developer to focus on the following. These grant funds will be used alongside grants from across Ethereum:
-	Integration of Commit-Boost with DVT solutions such as Obol and SSV
-	Build out a data base to support dashboards / transparency
-	Add more features such as slashing protection that has been requested by proposers / the Commit-Boost community (more details in our repo: https://github.com/Commit-Boost/commit-boost-client/issues)

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the decentralization and security of the Ethereum network?
questions.explanation:
**Decentralization**
Commit-Boost enhances decentralization by:
-	Empowering Ethereum‚Äôs 1M+ proposers to set constraints on downstream actors in the PBS (Proposer-Builder Separation) pipeline, such as builders, giving them greater autonomy.
-	Ensuring accessibility for all proposers, including solo stakers and DVT (Distributed Validator Technology) users, keeping Ethereum‚Äôs proposer set decentralized.
-	Maintaining an open standard that anyone can build on, preventing vendor lock-in. By fostering greater competition and diversity among builders and other network participants, Commit-Boost strengthens Ethereum‚Äôs decentralization.

**Security**
Commit-Boost improves security by:
-	Providing a unified sidecar, which:
-	1) Reduces risks during hard forks by consolidating multiple competing standards into a single, well-integrated standard that directly interacts with client software.
-	2) Minimizes attack vectors for stakers by reducing the number of sidecars they need to run.
-	Enhancing hard fork preparedness by enabling earlier testing of the PBS pipeline, identifying potential issues and risks before deployment. This not only improves the stability of hard forks but also reduces the workload for core developers, allowing them to focus on more critical tasks.
-	Being the only officially audited validator sidecar, with development contributions from proposers and 20+ teams across Ethereum. Commit-Boost has also undergone extensive testing on Holesky, ensuring reliability before deployment.
